prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Based on limiting existing observations of dense core kinematics with facilities such as CARMA, OVRO, and BIMA, we expect the brighter lines (N2H+, HCO+, HCN) to be 2-5 K after compensating for the smaller ALMA beam and the weaker lines (H13CO+, HNC, NH2D, 13CS) to be 1-2 K. Furthermore, depending on the kinematics of each core, the total linewidths may be quite narrow (on the order of 0.5-1 km/s) in some cases. We will thus integrate to a 1sigma rms of 0.2 K in 0.1 km/s channels, ensuring detections with S/N > 5 in all lines with sufficiently well-resolved lines to derive detailed kinematcs.
In order to recover all spatial scales and separate interferometer filtering from self-absorption indicative of infall, we must recover emission on size scales up to the full extents of cores (typically 10000 AU, or 40"). We thus require use of the ACA.
While our observations trigger the high data rate flag, this is unavoidable given our science goals. Accurate characterization of the dense core kinematics require a large suite of molecular line observations occupying all of the basebands except one, which is set to continuum. Furthermore, the narrow line-widths in low-mass cores (sometimes as narrow as 0.5 km/s) require the highest spectral resolution in order to fully resolve the lines and accurately determine the kinematic structure of the cores.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe 10 Class 0 protostars in Perseus in a suite of Band 3 dense gas tracers. These 10 protostars are selected from an ongoing VLA survey of multiplicity and disk formation in the complete population of Perseus protostars, and are chosen to form a statistically significant sample spanning the full range of multiplicity as revealed by the VLA. We will couple our observations with detailed line radiative transfer models to study the dense core kinematics in these objects, including the interplay between rotation, infall, and turbulence, and the link between these large-scale core kinematics and the outcomes of fragmentation and disk formation revealed by the VLA survey. Our proposed observations will emphasize the strong synergy possible between VLA and ALMA observations, and will shed new light on the processes governing the collapse of dense cores into stars.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
